title: Final Comprehensive Exam
description: A 50-question summative assessment covering all modules of the Nursing Research Methodology course (RES 303).

questions.question: According to Burns and Grove, how is research defined?

options.text: A diligent, systematic inquiry to validate and refine knowledge.
A casual observation of natural phenomena.
A method of treating patients based on tradition.
The collection of administrative hospital data.

questions.explanation: Burns and Grove define research as a diligent, systematic inquiry to validate and refine existing knowledge.
questions.hint: Think about systematic investigation.

questions.question: Match the source of knowledge with its definition.
questions.explanation: Tradition=customs, Authority=experts, Intuition=instinct, Experience=personal.
questions.hint: Think about how each knowledge type is acquired.

questions.question: What are the specific purposes of nursing research? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Nursing research aims to improve cost-effectiveness, quality assurance, and professional status.
questions.hint: Think about benefits to nursing practice.

questions.question: Which type of research is designed to produce findings for immediate practical application?
questions.explanation: Applied research produces findings for immediate practical application.
questions.hint: Think about solving practical problems.

questions.question: Qualitative research typically uses deductive reasoning.
questions.explanation: Qualitative research uses inductive reasoning; Quantitative uses deductive.
questions.hint: Qualitative builds theory from data.

questions.question: A ___BLANK___ study involves following the same group of people over various periods of time.
questions.explanation: A panel study follows the same group over time.
questions.hint: Think about studying the same people repeatedly.

questions.question: Which design looks back in time to link present outcomes to past exposures?
questions.explanation: Retrospective studies look back in time to link outcomes to exposures.
questions.hint: Think about looking backward.

questions.question: Which ethical principle includes the right to fair treatment and privacy?
questions.explanation: Justice includes fair treatment and privacy rights.
questions.hint: Think about fairness.

questions.question: It is ethical to withhold a known beneficial treatment from a control group in a clinical trial.
questions.explanation: Withholding known beneficial treatment is unethical.
questions.hint: Patient welfare comes first.

questions.question: ___BLANK___ means that the subject's identity cannot be linked, even by the researcher, to their individual responses.
questions.explanation: Anonymity means identity cannot be linked to responses.
questions.hint: Think about complete privacy.

questions.question: Which groups are considered vulnerable and require special protection? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Children, prisoners, and mentally impaired persons are vulnerable.
questions.hint: Think about who may have difficulty giving consent.

questions.question: Order the first 5 steps of the research process.
questions.explanation: Process: Identify Problem → Formulate Objectives → Justification → Literature Review → Methodology.
questions.hint: Start with what you want to study.

questions.question: In the study 'Effect of Diet on Weight', what is 'Weight'?
questions.explanation: Weight is the outcome variable (Dependent).
questions.hint: Think about what changes as a result.

questions.question: A ___BLANK___ hypothesis states that there is no relationship between variables.
questions.explanation: Null hypothesis states no relationship exists.
questions.hint: Think about 'no effect' hypothesis.

questions.question: Match the variable type.
questions.explanation: Independent=cause, Dependent=effect, Extraneous=uncontrolled, Demographic=attribute.
questions.hint: Think about the role of each variable.

questions.question: Which of the following is a PRIMARY source?
questions.explanation: Theses/Dissertations are primary sources (original works).
questions.hint: Primary sources are original.

questions.question: What citation style uses (Author, Year) in the text?
questions.explanation: APAD/APA uses (Author, Year) in text citations.
questions.hint: Think about common citation formats.

questions.question: Secondary sources are usually summaries or paraphrases of primary sources.
questions.explanation: Secondary sources summarize or paraphrase primary sources.
questions.hint: Secondary sources are one step removed.

questions.question: Ideally, you should review literature from the last ___BLANK___ years (maximum) for currency.
questions.explanation: Literature should ideally be from the last 10 years for currency.
questions.hint: Think about recent sources.

questions.question: Which design involves Manipulation, Control, and Randomization?
questions.explanation: True experimental designs require manipulation, control, and randomization.
questions.hint: Think about controlling variables.

questions.question: Which study design collects data at one specific point in time?
questions.explanation: Cross-sectional studies collect data at one point in time.
questions.hint: Think about taking a snapshot.

questions.question: Select the characteristics of a Case Study.
questions.explanation: Case studies provide depth, are time-consuming, and susceptible to dropout. They don't provide statistical generalization.
questions.hint: Think about studying one case in depth.

questions.question: Which sampling method involves selecting every 'kth' person from a list?
questions.explanation: Systematic sampling selects every kth person from a list.
questions.hint: Think about selecting at regular intervals.

questions.question: Match the sampling type.
questions.explanation: Purposive=judgmental, Snowball=referrals, Quota=proportions, Cluster=natural groups.
questions.hint: Think about how each method selects.

questions.question: A ___BLANK___ frame is a comprehensive list of all elements in the target population.
questions.explanation: A sampling frame is a complete list of population elements.
questions.hint: Think about what you sample from.

questions.question: Convenience sampling is a Probability sampling method.
questions.explanation: Convenience sampling is a Non-probability method.
questions.hint: Convenience doesn't use random selection.

questions.question: Which data collection method has the highest response rate?
questions.explanation: Face-to-face interviews have the highest response rate.
questions.hint: Think about personal interaction.

questions.question: What are advantages of Focus Group Discussions? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Focus groups are efficient, generate dialogue through group influence, and capture interaction depth. They don't ensure confidentiality.
questions.hint: Think about group dynamics.

questions.question: What type of question applies only to certain respondents (e.g., 'If yes, how many?')?
questions.explanation: Contingency or filter questions apply only to certain respondents.
questions.hint: Think about questions that depend on previous answers.

questions.question: Order the stages of data processing.
questions.explanation: Stages: Decide Format → Design Code → Code Data → Data Entry → Data Cleaning.
questions.hint: Start with planning how to organize data.

questions.question: What is 'Internal Validity'?

options.text: Control of extraneous variables within the study

questions.explanation: Internal validity is the degree to which extraneous variables are controlled.
questions.hint: Think about control within the study.

questions.question: Match the threat to validity.
questions.explanation: History=external events, Maturation=natural changes, Attrition=dropout, Instrumentation=tool unreliability.
questions.hint: Think about what each threat affects.

questions.question: What is the 'Hawthorne Effect'?

options.text: Subjects improve because they know they are observed
Improvement due to belief in treatment
Control group works harder to compete

questions.explanation: Hawthorne effect is when subjects improve due to being observed.
questions.hint: Think about the effect of being watched.

questions.question: The ___BLANK___ effect is when a control group performs better because they are competing with the experimental group.
questions.explanation: John Henry effect is when control group works harder to compete.
questions.hint: Think about competition between groups.

questions.question: Which scale has a true zero point?
questions.explanation: Ratio scale has a true zero point.
questions.hint: Think about measurements where zero means nothing.

questions.question: Which test analyzes the relationship between two categorical variables?
questions.explanation: Chi-square test analyzes relationships between categorical variables.
questions.hint: Think about tests for categorical data.

questions.question: A Type I error involves rejecting a true Null Hypothesis.
questions.explanation: Type I error is rejecting a true null hypothesis (false positive).
questions.hint: Type I is false positive.

questions.question: Which graphs are appropriate for continuous data? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Histograms and Frequency Polygons are for continuous data. Bar Charts and Pie Charts are for categorical.
questions.hint: Think about graphs for numerical data.

questions.question: A research proposal should be written in the past tense.
questions.explanation: Proposals use future tense; Reports use past tense.
questions.hint: Proposals describe what will be done.

questions.question: Order the standard sections of a research report.
questions.explanation: Order: Abstract → Introduction → Methodology → Results → Discussion.
questions.hint: Start with the summary.

questions.question: According to KMTC guidelines, where should the logo be placed on the proposal?

options.text: It should NOT be on the cover page

questions.explanation: KMTC guidelines state the logo should NOT be on the cover page.
questions.hint: Check KMTC formatting rules.

questions.question: The ___BLANK___ section interprets findings and links them to the hypothesis and literature.
questions.explanation: Discussion section interprets findings and links to hypothesis/literature.
questions.hint: Think about where you explain what results mean.

questions.question: What is a 'Refereed Journal'?

options.text: Uses subject experts to evaluate manuscripts (peer-review)
Is a magazine for the general public

questions.explanation: Refereed journals use peer review by subject experts.
questions.hint: Think about peer-reviewed journals.

questions.question: Match the research role.
questions.explanation: Evaluator critiques, User applies, PI leads, Advocate ensures ethics.
questions.hint: Think about different ways nurses engage with research.

questions.question: What is a 'Query Letter' used for?

options.text: To determine an editor's interest in a manuscript

questions.explanation: Query letters determine if an editor is interested in a manuscript.
questions.hint: Think about contacting a journal before submitting.

questions.question: Select barriers to research utilization.
questions.explanation: Lack of knowledge, negative attitudes, and lack of support are barriers.
questions.hint: Think about what prevents using research.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of good research?
questions.explanation: Good research should not be biased.
questions.hint: Think about what makes research poor quality.

questions.question: What is the subset of the population selected for study called?
questions.explanation: Sample is the subset of population selected for study.
questions.hint: Think about the group you actually study.

questions.question: Plagiarism involves using another person's work without acknowledgement.
questions.explanation: Plagiarism is using another's work without acknowledgment.
questions.hint: Always give credit to sources.

questions.question: Which chart type is best for displaying percentages/proportions?
questions.explanation: Pie charts are best for displaying percentages/proportions.
questions.hint: Think about showing parts of a whole.
